questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being tackled during a football match. The patient was knocked to the ground by another player. He experienced sudden-onset sharp pain in the abdomen and left shoulder. He subsequently lost consciousness. Before the incident, the patient had been experiencing fatigue and sore throat for two weeks. He has no significant past medical history and was screened with an ECG prior to playing football. At arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/60, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal guarding and rigidity. Elevation of the legs leads to the patient grimacing in pain and grabbing his left shoulder. Palpation of the left upper abdominal quadrant also causes the patient to grimace in pain. The bilateral tonsils are swollen and erythematous, and there is bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best explains this patient’s shoulder pain?

choices.text: Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset abdominal pain and hypotension after being tackled during a football match. In addition, he likely has concurrent infectious mononucleosis given his symptoms of fatigue, sore throat, and findings of swollen, erythematous tonsils bilaterally with posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. In combination, these findings are concerning for a splenic rupture and associated internal bleeding.    

The patient experienced left shoulder pain after the tackle and grimaces from left shoulder pain when the legs are elevated. This finding of left shoulder pain from irritation of the left diaphragm is known as the Kehr Sign. It is a classic example of referred pain. The pathophysiology of Kehr Sign is the same as that of other types of referred pain: visceral pain in one location of the body is interpreted as somatic pain in another due to effects of temporal and spatial summation of nerves arising from the same spinal level.    
In this case, splenic rupture and filling of the abdominal cavity with blood irritates the inferior surface of the left diaphragm. Irritation of the underside of the diaphragm is signaled by the phrenic nerve which carries pain signals up to spinal nerve levels C3 and C4. The supraclavicular nerve, which innervates the skin over the shoulder, also inserts at cervical levels C3 and C4. As a result, there is referred pain to the left shoulder from splenic rupture.  

Option Analysis

❌ Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force:
Incorrect: Shoulder dislocation does not explain this patient’s abdominal symptoms, head and neck findings, and hypotension. Splenic rupture associated with trauma in a patient with mononucleosis infection is more likely the cause of this constellation of findings.  
❌ Undiagnosed tumor:
Incorrect: An undiagnosed intra-abdominal malignancy would  likely present with insidious and chronic pain. This patient has acute onset abdominal pain and hypotension after a traumatic tackle and signs of mononucleosis which would indicate splenic rupture.  
❌ Impingement of the supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: Impingement of this nerve would cause pain in the shoulder area. However, it would not account for the patient’s abdominal pain, hypotension, and head and neck findings.  
❌ Atypical myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Although an atypical myocardial infarction can present with abdominal pain, it would not account for this patient’s symptoms of acute abdomen (e.g., diffuse guarding, rigidity), hypotension, and head and neck findings. Myocardial infarction would be unlikely in this young man with no prior medical history who had a screening ECG prior to playing sports.  
✅ Irritation of the diaphragm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the primary care office for an annual check-up. He was hospitalized four months ago for appendicitis which was managed with laparoscopic surgery.  He recovered well and has no complaints today. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Healed surgical scars are noted on the skin of the abdomen without erythema or drainage. A 2 cm non-tender, non-mobile bulge is seen and palpated at the right lower quadrant surgical scar. The bulge becomes more prominent with the Valsalva maneuver and reduces spontaneously with relaxation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents without symptoms but is incidentally found to have a non-tender, reducible bulge at the site of a prior surgical incision. These findings are consistent with an asymptomatic incisional hernia.  His history of smoking may have contributed to poor wound healing after surgery, leading to a defect in the abdominal wall.

When abdominal contents protrude through a defect in the anterior wall, it is referred to as a ventral hernia.  Hernias are considered incisional when the defect is associated with a prior surgical site.  Risk factors for developing a hernia following surgery include smoking, inadequate nutrition, obesity, and immunosuppression. These factors can lead to impaired wound healing.  Defects that are not caused by surgery are usually the result of high intra-abdominal pressure such as repetitive heavy lifting, trauma, repeated weight loss with subsequent weight gain, pregnancy, constipation, or severe coughing.

Physical examination of a patient with a ventral or incisional hernia will show a bulge in the abdominal wall which increases with Valsalva maneuvers.  It may be possible to hear bowel sounds when auscultating over the mass.  Tenderness may or may not be present.  If the hernia becomes incarcerated, the area will become tender to palpation, and erythema of the skin may occur.  In strangulated hernias, the skin can become dusky or erythematous, with severe tenderness of the mass, and signs of bowel obstruction or sepsis may be present.

Option Analysis

✅ Incisional hernia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diastasis recti:
Incorrect:  Diastasis recti refers to the separation of the rectus muscles at the midline and is a distinct entity from an abdominal wall hernia.  This patient has classic findings of an asymptomatic incisional hernia in the right lower abdomen.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma is caused by arterial bleeding usually secondary to trauma and leads to abdominal pain and a tender mass in the abdominal wall.  This patient does not have pain, tenderness, or a history of trauma.  
❌ Skin abscess:
Incorrect:  Wound infection is a possible complication after surgery, however, this patient had surgery four months ago and does not have pain or redness of the skin which makes abscess less likely.  
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect:  A lipoma refers to a fatty tumor that may present as a painful or asymptomatic mass in the abdominal wall.  A lipoma would not increase in size with Valsalva maneuvers and it is often mobile below the skin's surface. This patient’s mass lies in close proximity to a surgical scar and changes on Valsalva; therefore it is consistent with an incisional hernia.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the office with anal pain and malodorous drainage from the area for the past 2 days. The pain is worse with prolonged sitting and defecation. The patient has a history of a prior procedure to drain a perianal abscess. She has Crohn disease and takes infliximab. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, and respirations are 15/min. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Anal examination reveals an indurated, erythematous region in the perianal area with an external opening and drainage. Anoscopy shows another erythematous opening inside the anus. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test to order at this time?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis
Computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with Crohn disease has anal pain, malodorous drainage, and 2 erythematous openings (one external to the anus and another observed with anoscopy inside the anus). These features are concerning for a perianal fistula, and an MRI of the pelvis should be obtained to confirm this diagnosis and to determine whether the fistula is simple or complex in order to guide management.

A perianal fistula can develop between the anal canal and the perianal area after a perianal abscess drains (spontaneously or surgically). The fistula is lined with inflammatory tissue and is maintained by persistent crypt blockage.

Patients with a perianal fistula typically present with intermittent perianal pain that worsens with sitting, activity, or defecation. This can be associated with intermittent, malodorous drainage and pruritus. Physical examination can reveal an excoriated, indurated external tract opening, a non-healing abscess, or chronic purulent drainage. Digital rectal examination may reveal a palpable internal opening or deep abscess. Laboratory studies may reveal leukocytosis.

Patients who are suspected of having a perianal fistula should undergo anoscopy or sigmoidoscopy to identify an internal opening in the anus or rectum. If one is identified, an MRI of the pelvis or endosonography should be obtained. MRI is the most sensitive and specific modality for identifying and classifying fistulas as simple or complex, which will determine management.

A fistula is defined as simple when the tract is intersphincteric, or low transsphincteric (crossing < 30% of the external anal sphincter). Complex fistulas can be diagnosed when MRI or endosonography demonstrates external sphincter involvement greater than or equal to 30%; a fistula that is proximal to the dentate line, or the presence of a multiple-tract fistula.  The presence of recurrent fistulas or anal incontinence can also be used to classify a fistula as complex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While this patient has a perianal condition that needs to be further evaluated, MRI of the pelvis will provide more detail than a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.  
❌ Culture of the drainage:
Incorrect: Culturing the drainage will be helpful for tailoring antibiotics; however, a pelvic MRI should be performed as the next step to confirm the diagnosis, determine the complexity of the fistula, and guide the next steps in management.  
❌ Sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: Since an internal opening was seen during anoscopy, sigmoidoscopy is not necessary and would not add any additional information.  
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: A barium enema does not show the surrounding tissue involvement of a perianal fistula. MRI of the pelvis should be used to confirm the diagnosis of a perianal fistula and provide information to determine further management.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient was driving on the highway and was rear-ended by another vehicle. She is experiencing left sided abdominal pain rated as a seven out of ten in severity. Medical history is notable for hypertension and a recently diagnosed deep vein thrombosis which is being treated with apixaban. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 163/99 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination reveals bruising and a painful non-pulsatile mass in the left upper abdominal wall. There is no evidence of head or neck injury, and there is no tenderness to palpation along the spine. CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis reveals the findings seen below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain and the presence of an abdominal wall mass after a motor vehicle accident. She was taking oral anticoagulants at the time of the accident. Imaging reveals asymmetrical enlargement of the left rectus abdominis muscle indicated by the yellow arrow below. These findings are concerning for a rectus sheath hematoma.   

A rectus sheath hematoma is an accumulation of blood within the sheath of the rectus abdominis muscle. It typically occurs due to an injury to the epigastric artery or one of its branches, either due to abdominal trauma or forceful contractions of the abdominal wall.  

A focused history may reveal important risk factors such as anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy, recent abdominal surgery or trauma, pregnancy, female biological sex, and chronic conditions (e.g., renal disease, cirrhosis, hypertension). Additionally, patients with a history of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease may be at an increased risk due to repeated and forceful contractions of the rectus abdominis muscle during coughing spells.  

Physical examination typically reveals abdominal wall ecchymosis and a tender, palpable, and non-pulsating abdominal mass. A positive Fothergill sign (the abdominal mass remains fixed in position when the patient contracts abdominal muscles), and a positive Carnett sign can indicate a rectus sheath hematoma. The Carnett sign helps determine if the abdominal pain originates from the abdominal wall muscles or intra-abdominally. The patient is asked to relax and the abdomen is palpated to localize the pain. Then the patient is asked to contract their abdominal muscles and the same spot is palpated. If the pain worsens, it is from the abdominal wall.  


Option Analysis

❌ Pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoperitoneum describes the presence of free air within the abdominal cavity. While traumatic injury can lead to bowel perforation, there is no evidence of free air on this CT. Instead, this patient has asymmetrical enlargement of the left rectus abdominis muscle. These findings are concerning for a rectus sheath hematoma.  
❌ Liver laceration:
Incorrect: Traumatic injury can lead to liver laceration. Patients can develop liver parenchymal bleeding, subcapsular hematoma, and blood loss. However, the patient's liver appears grossly unremarkable on the CT scan and the pain and mass are localized to the left hemiabdomen.  
✅ Rectus sheath hematoma   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal wall contusion   :
Incorrect: This patient has mild fat stranding in the left anterior abdominal wall, which suggests soft tissue contusions. Additionally, the patient has asymmetrical enlargement of the left rectus abdominis muscle indicating a rectus sheath hematoma, which would better account for the patient’s abdominal pain and non-pulsatile mass.  
❌ Chance fracture  :
Incorrect: A Chance fracture typically involves the thoracolumbar junction and occurs due to hyperflexion. The injury classically occurs in individuals involved in a motor vehicle collision while wearing a lap seatbelt, which acts as a flexion fulcrum. This patient does not have imaging or physical examination findings suggesting a Chance fracture.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining an injury. While working as a gardener, he lost his balance while trimming a tree and fell off a 10-foot ladder. The patient has chest and abdominal pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and von Willebrand disease. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 170/85 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination reveals a painful non-pulsatile mass in the left upper abdominal wall with surrounding bruising. The mass remains fixed when the patient contracts the rectus muscles. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast is obtained. Which of the following findings on CT would indicate a type III (most severe) classification of this patient’s underlying pathology?

choices.text: Hematoma located within the rectus abdominis muscle dissecting along the transv
Diffuse soft tissue stranding in the abdominal wall
Hematoma confined within the rectus abdominis muscle without extension
Hematoma located within the rectus abdominis muscle and crossing the midline
Large hematoma below the arcuate line extending into the peritoneal space

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of trauma and an inherited bleeding disorder (von Willebrand disease) and presents with a painful non-pulsatile mass in the left upper abdomen. The Fothergill sign is positive (the abdominal mass remains fixed in position when the patient contracts abdominal muscles), suggesting an abdominal wall etiology. In combination, these findings are concerning for a rectus sheath hematoma.  

Once a rectus sheath hematoma is suspected a CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast should be performed to classify the hematoma and guide management. Depending on the degree to which blood extends beyond the rectus abdominis muscle, rectus sheath hematomas can be classified as type I, II, or III. If the hematoma is contained solely within the rectus abdominis muscle, it is considered type I. If the hematoma is within the rectus abdominis muscle and crosses the midline or dissects along the transversalis fascial plane, it is a type II rectus sheath hematoma. Finally, if the hematoma is large and extends below the arcuate line into the peritoneum or perivesical space, it is considered a type III rectus sheath hematoma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hematoma located within the rectus abdominis muscle dissecting along the transv:
Incorrect: Rectus sheath hematomas that are confined within the rectus abdominis muscle but cross the midline or transect along the transversalis fascial plane are considered type II rectus sheath hematomas.  
❌ Diffuse soft tissue stranding in the abdominal wall  :
Incorrect: Soft tissue standing is a nonspecific imaging finding. In the setting of trauma, it may represent soft tissue contusions. The presence or absence of soft tissue stranding is not used to classify rectus sheath hematomas.  
❌ Hematoma confined within the rectus abdominis muscle without extension  :
Incorrect: A hematoma located only within the rectus abdominis muscle that does not cross the midline or dissect fascial planes is classified as a type I (least severe) rectus sheath hematoma.  
❌ Hematoma located within the rectus abdominis muscle and crossing the midline  :
Incorrect:  Rectus sheath hematomas that are confined within the rectus abdominis muscle but cross the midline or transect along the transversalis fascial plane are considered type II rectus sheath hematomas.   
✅ Large hematoma below the arcuate line extending into the peritoneal space  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department after being punched in the chest and abdomen and thrown into the edge of a table. The patient was at a bar when he got involved in a physical altercation with another patron. He is currently experiencing severe abdominal pain. He has a past medical history of von Willebrand disease and stage II chronic kidney disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 150/92 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min. Physical examination reveals bruising in the anterior chest and abdominal wall. There is a painful non-pulsatile mass in the right mid-abdomen. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast reveals a type II rectus sheath hematoma. The patient is treated initially with conservative therapy, but on follow up exam, he continues to have severe abdominal pain, and the mass is felt to be enlarging. Follow up bloodwork shows decreasing hemoglobin. Repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast show a right rectus sheath hematoma with a circular hyperdense focus in the center of the hematoma. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Continued application of ice and compression

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of a bleeding disorder and has a type II rectus sheath hematoma following abdominal trauma. Despite conservative therapy, a repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast reveals a rectus sheath hematoma with active contrast extravasation (blush)  indicating ongoing bleeding. Angioembolization should be performed to stop the bleeding.  

A rectus sheath hematoma is the accumulation of blood within the sheath of the rectus abdominis muscle. Type I rectus sheath hematomas are characterized by bleeding confined to the unilateral muscle. They typically can be managed in the outpatient setting with conservative therapy including bedrest, ice, and compression to the affected area. If the patient is on anticoagulation therapy, it may need to be adjusted or discontinued.   

Type II rectus sheath hematomas are characterized by blood extending along the transversalis fascial plane or crossing the midline. Type III hematomas are characterized by the extension of blood into the peritoneum or perivesical space. Patients with either type II or type III hematomas should be treated as inpatients with initial conservative therapy, IV hydration, anticoagulant reversal if necessary, and they should be followed with serial hemoglobin and hematocrit levels to determine if blood products need to be transfused. If these patients don’t respond to conservative treatment, become unstable, or if  CT scans show extravasation indicating continuous bleeding, then angioembolization should be performed. If this is ineffective or patients show signs of shock or compressive symptoms (e.g., neuropathy, hydronephrosis), then surgery is indicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ Angioembolization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serial serum lipase levels  :
Incorrect: Serum lipase and amylase levels are typically followed in patients with acute pancreatitis which can present with severe abdominal pain. The cause of this patient's ongoing severe abdominal pain is a type II rectus sheath hematoma that is expanding from active bleeding.    
❌ Continued application of ice and compression  :
Incorrect: This patient has a right-sided type II rectus sheath hematoma that has been enlarging with continued bleeding despite conservative therapy. Conservative therapy with ice and compression is not sufficient treatment at this time and angioembolization or surgical ligation should be performed to stop the bleeding.  
❌ Administration of protamine sulfate  :
Incorrect: Protamine sulfate can reverse the effects of heparin. However, this patient is not taking heparin. As a result, protamine sulfate would have little or no effect on stopping this patient’s abdominal    wall bleeding.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy  :
Incorrect: The patient has a right-sided rectus sheath hematoma with an internal hyperintense focus, that is concerning for contrast extravasation and continuous active bleeding. Laparotomy should be performed only as a last resort and often poses a greater risk of bleeding, especially in patients with underlying coagulopathies. Angioembolization should be attempted first to stop the bleeding.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man develops sudden-onset crampy abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea on day 7 of his hospital admission for acute myocardial infarction. The pain initially began in the left lower abdomen but has now become diffuse. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and a 35-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 94/62 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and diaphoretic. Abdominal examination reveals a rigid distended abdomen with diffuse abdominal tenderness, and guarding. Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm³ and a lactate level of 4.5 mmol/L. Intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Upright chest radiograph shows no evidence of pneumoperitoneum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy
Supportive care with bowel rest and observation

questions.solution:
This hospitalized patient has developed crampy abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, tachycardia, and hypotension. These findings, along with an elevated lactate level and acute abdomen on examination strongly suggest a diagnosis of colonic ischemia. In addition to IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics, emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy is the best next step in management.

In addition to providing immediate care for patients presenting with acute lower abdominal pain which may include supplemental oxygen, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and broad-spectrum antibiotics, it is crucial to exclude life-threatening conditions such as acute mesenteric ischemia, ischemic colitis, and abdominal aortic aneurysm which are all indications for emergent exploratory laparotomy. Another indication for emergency surgery in patients experiencing abdominal pain is the presence of findings suggestive of an acute abdomen and peritonitis. These may include severe distension with rigidity, diffuse tenderness, rebound, and guarding on physical examination, or pneumoperitoneum detected on abdominal imaging.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT angiography:
Incorrect: CT angiography may be used for diagnosing embolic causes of abdominal pain in stable patients. This patient’s hemodynamic instability and clinical findings consistent with an acute abdomen and history consistent with ischemic colitis warrant emergent surgical consultation. Obtaining a CT angiogram would delay emergent surgical intervention.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Although a colonoscopy can confirm the diagnosis of ischemic colitis in stable patients, it should not be performed in patients who have signs of acute peritonitis and instability. This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests colonic ischemia with an acute abdomen necessitating urgent surgical intervention.  
❌ Administration of IV heparin infusion:
Incorrect: Although IV heparin infusion may be an option for managing specific thromboembolic causes of ischemia, typically mesenteric ischemia, it is not appropriate for this patient.  
❌ Supportive care with bowel rest and observation:
Incorrect: Supportive care, including bowel rest and observation, may be suitable for stable patients with self-limited causes of lower abdominal pain, such as infectious gastritis or simple mechanical small bowel obstruction. However, this patient's clinical presentation suggestive of colonic ischemia and instability requires emergent surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with worsening periumbilical abdominal pain for the past 24 hours. He describes the pain as crampy and intermittent, occurring every 15-20 minutes. The patient also reports nausea, vomiting, an inability to pass gas, and constipation. He has a history of an appendectomy 25 years ago. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.  On examination, the abdomen is distended and tympanic to percussion with hyperactive bowel sounds. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of prior abdominal surgery, presents with periumbilical abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to pass gas and stool, and physical exam findings of a tympanic abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds, suggesting a small bowel obstruction. The most appropriate next step in evaluation, in this case, is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

For patients presenting with periumbilical and lower abdominal pain history and physical examination should guide the diagnostic testing. Laboratory tests may include CBC, CMP, CRP, ESR, urinalysis, and lactate levels. Imaging studies such as plain abdominal radiography, abdominal US, CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, MRI of the abdomen, and endoscopic evaluations may be performed.

The location of pain can provide essential clues to the underlying etiology. Some common causes of lower abdominal pain include appendicitis, Crohn’s disease, nephrolithiasis, ovarian cyst or torsion, diverticulitis, sigmoid volvulus, urinary tract infection, pelvic inflammatory disease, endometriosis, bowel obstruction, colonic or mesenteric ischemia. The location of the pain can help narrow the differential diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable with suspected small bowel obstruction. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis should be performed as it can accurately identify the level and cause of obstruction, as well as assess for complications.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen:
Incorrect: Although MRI of the abdomen is highly sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of bowel obstruction, it may not be readily available, has a longer scan time, and may not be as reliable in identifying the cause of obstruction compared to a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. It is reserved for cases where a CT scan is contraindicated.  
❌ Right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are not consistent with RUQ pathology such as gallbladder disease or liver disease. An ultrasound of the right upper quadrant would not provide useful information in this case.  
❌ Water-soluble contrast study:
Incorrect: Although a water-soluble contrast study can be used in the evaluation and management of bowel obstruction, it is not the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in this case. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis can provide more detailed information about the location, cause, and potential complications of an obstruction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of three days of worsening pain over the tailbone and the presence of a lump in that area. Sitting, walking, and stretching the skin over the area worsens the pain. He has noticed foul-smelling drainage on his underwear. Bowel movements are painless and non-bloody. The patient has no dysuria or urinary frequency. He has not had any recent falls or injuries. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient drives a truck for work. Temperature is 39<sup>o</sup>C (102.2 <sup>o</sup>F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. What findings are most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Erythema and a tender fluctuant mass over the top of the natal cleft
Longitudinal tear in the posterior midline of the anal mucosa
Tender purple mass in the perianal area

questions.solution:
This patient’s history is most consistent with pilonidal disease, which can present as an acute infection with associated abscess formation. Pilonidal disease occurs when a pore or pit forms at the top of the natal cleft (gluteal cleft) of the intergluteal or sacrococcygeal region.

Pilonidal disease often develops from mechanical forces causing skin irritation. Skin and hair follicles trap hair or other skin debris which can lead to infection and abscess formation.  Sinus tracts may develop and communicate to the outer skin layer with or without associated drainage which can be bloody, purulent, or mucoid.

Acute pilonidal infection presents with pain with compression and with movements that cause stretching of the overlying skin. Fever may be present. Retraction of the buttock cheeks may reveal erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the affected area along the gluteal cleft. Pits or pores may be seen. A painful fluctuant area or lump, with or without drainage, suggests that an abscess has formed.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema and a tender fluctuant mass over the top of the natal cleft:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Longitudinal tear in the posterior midline of the anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Anal fissures typically cause significant pain and associated blood with bowel movements.  
❌ Tender prostate gland:
Incorrect: Infection of the prostate gland, or prostatitis, can produce perianal pain, but the patient would be expected to have dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and cloudy urine.  
❌ Ecchymosis over the coccyx:
Incorrect: Injury to the coccyx can cause pain in the region, but the patient has not had a significant injury.  
❌ Tender purple mass in the perianal area:
Incorrect: A thrombosed external hemorrhoid would cause significant pain, especially with bowel movements. It is not typically associated with fever.
